channel.title: The perfect murder?
channel.description:
We all know that murder is bad, that's what we've been taught since we were kids (well most of us) but there are definitely people out there that the would would benefit from being gone (KKK members, other murders). What do you think would happen if lets say I shot a KKK leader during one of his hate speeches and he died. I willingly put on handcuffs and admit that I am the one who shot and at the court case I say I am the one who shot him. What would happen? Would the basic legal system go with normal rules (30 to life for manslaughter) or would the jury find the killing just and my sentence would be low or non at all?
Now hold on, I know you think I'm crazy that I would think the second answer would even be a possibility in this day and age, but think just to yourself. Is it really evil if the acts of evil are preformed on the evil itself? I've seen cases before that people have point blank said they killed someone, but the person they killed was so hated/despised that the case was just dropped.
/Discuss

item.title: The perfect murder?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Andrew Ferguson, post:79, topic:425250”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=527913.msg3850130#msg3850130 date=1323959087]

[quote author=m1lkman link=topic=527913.msg3850125#msg3850125 date=1323958851]

I have my opinion. You shouldn’t dog on me because I have my own beliefs. It just makes you look stupid and ignorant.

It’s wrong, God will take care of him (KKK leader). I will stand up and cheer when he is punished.

Though I respect the idea that you believe in a god you can’t really sit back and wait for an outside force to take action.

That’s where we disagree. I have faith that if it is in God’s plan, he will be killed. I can sit back. Now if this person committed murder and the police catch him, a justifiable murder would be the death sentence. We shouldn’t take matters into our own hands.
[/quote]The death sentence is equal to murder regardless. Should we punish the executor with a death sentence too?

I have no idea where you’re getting this “similarity” stuff from. There is no more similarity between murder and capital punishment than there is between kidnapping and locking someone in prison, or between stealing money and paying a fine. In other words, there may be some superficial similarity, but it’s purely coincidental. What makes execution fitting for some crimes is the severity, not any imagined “similarity”. That’s why people think different crimes can call for the death penalty (e.g. child molestation). If life imprisonment is as severe as execution, then you should feel the same about both of them, and if it isn’t, then it can hardly be an acceptable substitute.
[/quote]I agree with the scientific world in this matter. Punishment is a bad thing, rehabilitation is a good thing. There’s a reason the scandinavian countries have some of the highest rehabilitation figures in the world. An executed man can’t help society, a rehabilitated ex-criminal can.

Some men are past the point of being rehabilitated however and the only real thing they can do from then on to benefit society is to no longer be apart of it.[/quote]Those are very few, but yes, that is a problem.
